Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-VIGRE: Leveraging the Strength and Extending the Reach of an Integrated Mathematics Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vertically integrated cross-disciplinary research groups (known as PFUGs, an acronym for "Postdoctoral, Faculty, Undergraduate, and Graduate Research Groups") are now proud, shared emblems of the three departments (Computational and Applied Mathematics, Statistics, and Mathematics) that partnered in the Rice VIGRE I project and will continue that partnership in VIGRE II. PFUGs have become a way of life for the departments? existing majors and graduate students and excellent avenues for engaging and recruiting a broad array of talent.

Under VIGRE II the three departments will sustain, expand, and leverage these successes as Rice itself enters a phase of rapid growth. Under VIGRE II every undergraduate major in any of the three departments will experience mathematical research. VIGRE II will extend the reach of PFUGs to departments and institutions at further distance from the traditional mathematical sciences departments. In addition, while the project will maintain many of its ongoing research programs, VIGRE II will also annually pursue a single new theme that not only engages all strata of all three mathematics departments but also draws in and significantly impacts a strategic area of application, such as the life sciences, finance, or information technology. Finally, VIGRE II will exploit "Connexions" to improve radically the existing mechanisms for constructing and disseminating findings. "Connexions" is a Rice-based collection of tools to create modules that can be related to each other in multiple ways and that can be organized so as to produce books or courses or short documents or just browsed online. Students, with help from communication professionals, will learn to keep research logs that, with careful editing and design, could evolve into modules. These PFUGal variations will be folded into a narrative on "The Art of the PFUG" that will serve as a national model for vertical integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award facilitated the annual establishment of 10 to 15 research groups across the mathematical sciences at Rice University. The average group had robust representation from our undergraduate, graduate, post-doctoral and faculty populations. These rare combinations provided our

(a) undergraduates with several windows onto the research world that awaits them as graduate students,

(b) graduate students with additional supportive mentors as well as a detailed look at the post-doctoral world that awaits them,

(c) post-docs with a close faculty mentor and the opportunity to direct and mentor research assistants, and

(d) faculty with very talented young research colleagues and the opportunity to influence and mentor a large group with no greater time commitment than that needed to mentor one or two students individually.

As all players viewed these changes as positive, our institutional culture indeed changed. Groups like these, once rare, now exist annually as a permanent part of the curriculum. In addition, with over 150 veterans of our program now successful graduate students, postdocs and faculty at a diverse array of institutions our model is one of many that departments may invoke when contemplating means to overcome the inclination to insular overspecialization that impedes the broader participation in, and dissemination of, mathematics.

The economy of scale mentioned in part (d) above also permitted us to make maximal use of communication specialists outside of our departments. This in turn lead us to significantly, and successfully, increase our quality expectations of oral, poster and written presentations from each of our populations.

Each of these innovations increased the productivity and both broadened the sphere of influence of individual faculty members and dramatically lowered the anxiety levels of students and postdocs as they approached the next stage in their careers.

Beyond the nucleation of these small topical research groups we also engaged in two successful outreach efforts. We offered annual, big tent, survey seminars on broad topics such as Image Processing and Network Theory. Though these indeed attracted presenters and participants from across the sciences and engineering we tripled our impact when we shifted to full semester surveys of the work and legacy of such broad minds as Henri Poincare and Norbert Wiener.

Our second outreach effort brought 20 high school students, each week, from an underserved Houston neighborhood into research groups composed, as above, of undergrads, graduate students, postdocs and faculty. This provided our Rice students the opportunity to mentor and direct research in a structured supportive environment and our High School students with an opportunity to imagine themselves as college students.
